title: 106_hr3479
content: The Act titled "Small Business Disaster Assistance Act of 1999" provides disaster assistance to reopen small business concerns and agricultural enterprises. Section 7 of the Small Business Act is amended to allow the Administration to make grants and loans for disaster assistance programs to reopen small business concerns and agricultural enterprises following a natural or other disaster. The Small Business Act is amended to allow grants for disaster assistance programs to reopen small businesses and agricultural enterprises after a disaster. Eligibility criteria include being a viable business at the time of the disaster and likely to remain viable after receiving assistance. Grants cannot exceed $30,000. The Small Business Act allows for grants to assist small businesses and agricultural enterprises after a disaster. Grants must be disbursed promptly after the disaster. The Administration may also provide loans to help small businesses reopen and stay open, either directly or in partnership with lending institutions. The Small Business Act allows for grants and loans to assist small businesses and agricultural enterprises after a disaster. Loans can be provided on an immediate or deferred basis with a one-year deferral for repayment. Repaid amounts are applied to the principal of the loan. The Small Business Act provides grants and loans to assist small businesses and agricultural enterprises after a disaster. Assistance is limited to those not in default of federal obligations, child support, or court judgments. Recipients must use the funds for repairing or replacing items and structures. The Small Business Act provides grants and loans to assist small businesses and agricultural enterprises after a disaster. Recipients must use the funds for repairing or replacing items and structures that were lost or damaged as a result of the disaster. Additionally, recipients operating in flood-prone locations must obtain flood insurance for their structures and contents. The Small Business Act provides grants and loans to assist small businesses and agricultural enterprises after a disaster. Recipients must use the funds for repairing or replacing items and structures that were lost or damaged. Additionally, businesses operating in flood-prone locations must maintain flood insurance for their structures and contents. Agricultural enterprises are defined as farms not larger than a family farm. Regulations must be consulted before implementing these requirements. When implementing regulations, the Administration must consult the Secretary of Agriculture regarding their impact on agricultural enterprises. Section 4(f)(1) of the Small Business Act is amended to reference "section 459 of the Social Security Act" instead of "section 462(b)". These amendments apply to major disasters declared after September 1, 1999.
